subject: bug #941794 VIF and intf drivers for Quantum Linux Bridge plugin
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 447, 'name': 'dan wendlandt', 'email': 'dan@nicira.com', 'username': 'danwent'}, {'_account_id': 490, 'name': 'Sumit Naiksatam', 'email': 'sumitnaiksatam@gmail.com', 'username': 'snaiksat'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1689, 'name': 'Robert Kukura', 'email': 'rk@theep.net', 'username': 'rkukura'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-02-27 11:57:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Couple of comments.."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-02-27 19:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Discussions related to quantum bug 925074 seemed to conclude that these drivers could be run from the quantum namespace, and no longer needed to be copied into nova. Are you sure they need to be moved to nova?'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-02-28 04:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Bob, my experiments have shown that these drivers cannot be run from the quantum namespace in all cases; devstack is one such example where nova and the api server are not able to find the modules from the quantum namespace. Hence, I am proposing that they be included here. Besides, there is already a precedent set by the ovs drivers, which I am merely trying to follow (and as was also suggested by one of the Quantum reviewers).'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-28 06:51:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm ok with these going in if it is necessary as it doesn't touch any core code. That said it would be really good to figure out why importing in devstack is not working, though. The setup.py develop command should give access to the other components that are setup."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-02-28 07:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Vish, I had the stack.sh script modified to have the flags set as follows:

        add_nova_flag "--libvirt_vif_driver=quantum.plugins.linuxbridge.nova.vif_linuxbridge_quantum.QuantumLibvirtLinuxBridgeVIFDriver"
        add_nova_flag "--linuxnet_interface_driver=quantum.plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge.QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver"

However, the nova-api server fails to come up with the error that it cannot find the nova.linux_net_linux_bridge module:

2012-02-27 20:03:28 DEBUG nova.utils [-] Inner Exception: No module named nova.linux_net_linux_bridge from (pid=25443) import_class /opt/stack/nova/nova/utils.py:74
2012-02-27 20:03:28 CRITICAL nova [-] Class QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver could not be found: No module named nova.linux_net_linux_bridge

Do you suggest doing something differently?

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-28 07:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I did a little investigation and this looks like a naming conflict between quantum and python-quantumclient.  The directory in python-quantumclient should probably be changed to quantumclient instead of quantum. Otherwise there is an import conflict if both of them are installed.

Vish'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-28 07:56:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

cancel that. I didn't realize quantum was using pkgutils to put multiple projects in the same namespace. So I can get the import class to work ok when I run it manually if I have ensured that I have run python setup.py develop on both quantum and python-quantumclient. Is it possible that those commands haven't been run in your devstack instance?"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-02-28 08:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Changing the namespace in python-quantumclient would probably be a much bigger change since everything that is currently using it would have to change the imports, right? And if that is the case, I don't think we would attempt that in Quantum at this time.

Also, since these drivers actually extend the nova driver interfaces and rely on the nova libraries, I think they should logically be in the nova code. That would make testing easier as well (since quantum does not have nova as a dependency, so no tests can be run against these in that repo). What do you think? I would imagine that the OVS driver code was included here for the same reason."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-28 08:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

setup.py develop seems to solve it.  Can you try? (see my shell paste below)
vagrant@nova:/opt/stack/quantum$ /opt/stack/nova/bin/nova-manage sh p
Python 2.7.2+ (default, Oct  4 2011, 20:06:09) 
[GCC 4.6.1] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
(InteractiveConsole)
>>> from nova import utils
>>> utils.import_class("quantum.plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge.QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver")
2012-02-28 08:07:47 DEBUG nova.utils [-] Inner Exception: No module named plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge from (pid=5472) import_class /opt/stack/nova/nova/utils.py:76
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/stack/nova/nova/utils.py", line 77, in import_class
    raise exception.ClassNotFound(class_name=class_str, exception=exc)
ClassNotFound: Class QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver could not be found: No module named plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge
>>> 
vagrant@nova:/opt/stack/quantum$ sudo python setup.py develop
running develop
Checking .pth file support in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/
...
vagrant@nova:/opt/stack/quantum$ /opt/stack/nova/bin/nova-manage sh p
Python 2.7.2+ (default, Oct  4 2011, 20:06:09) 
[GCC 4.6.1] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
(InteractiveConsole)
>>> from nova import utils
>>> utils.import_class("quantum.plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge.QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver")
<class 'quantum.plugins.linuxbridge.nova.linux_net_linux_bridge.QuantumLinuxBridgeInterfaceDriver'>
>>>'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-28 08:13:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Also, since these drivers actually extend the nova driver interfaces and rely on the nova libraries, I think they should logically be in the nova code. That would make testing easier as well (since quantum does not have nova as a dependency, so no tests can be run against these in that repo). What do you think? I would imagine that the OVS driver code was included here for the same reason.

I buy that logic. If they make more sense here we can put them in.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-02-28 09:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-02-28 09:28:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Per Vish's comments proceeding with this checkin.

I have addressed Soren's comments and uploaded a new patch. Kindly review.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-02-28 11:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-29 18:37:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think the patch needs a unit test added to test_libvirt_vif.py

The LOG.debug("plug") and LOG.debug("unplug") messages also seem like they could be removed.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-01 00:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-01 00:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Per Dan's comments I have added the unit test, and removed the debug statements."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-03-02 03:35:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-02 15:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

2 minor comments.

1. It would be better to keep a short first line <60 chars or so, in the commit message, and then separate the rest of the message with a blank line.

2. You may want to update some of the comments in rootwrap/*
to align with the new usage locations of the existing filters'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:33:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi p-draigbrady, Thanks for your review. I have addressed your first comment. However, I am not sure I understand your second comment. My guess is that it does not apply to this patch since I am not changing any existing Nova behavior with respect to filters.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-02 23:31:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

he means in nova/rootwrap/compute.py and network.py there are comments saying where the commands you are using are used in the code base. You could update those comments to refer to your new usages of 'ip' etc.

Also, if you are updating that please switch the first two lines of your commit message so that the description is first."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-03 02:36:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-03 02:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thanks Vish, done.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-03 02:38:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-03 09:58:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Please remove the new tunctl filter from rootwrap/network.py
Instead just move the associated comment to the existing entry in rootwrap/compute.py

sorry for the churn"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-03 10:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-03-03 10:20:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks p-draigbrady, done.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-03 11:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

thanks!'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-03-05 12:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-05 18:55:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 19:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

subject: Move console to a ringbuffer
messages: [{'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-03-05 18:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-05 18:38:09.000000000', 'message': "Move console to a ringbuffer

This patch is based on the original patch by Robie Basak
in I6b4794419509e0f9b71c8be9f235d8d999baa884.

Prevent a DoS by storing console output in a ringbuffer on the host,
instead of allowing it to grow indefinitely. Fixes bug 832507.

This patch has been updated for Essex. I have added a
libvirt flag called 'libvirt_console_buffer' which allows the
user to use the console ringbuffer, which allows this option to be
configurable. It is turned off by default.

Change-Id: Ida23f885ad51e6635b6704294bf7ea3c5322ef0b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Robie Basak <robie.basak@canonical.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Move console to a ringbuffer

This patch is based on the original patch by Robie Basak
in I6b4794419509e0f9b71c8be9f235d8d999baa884.

Prevent a DoS by storing console output in a ringbuffer on the host,
instead of allowing it to grow indefinitely. Fixes bug 832507.

This patch has been updated for Essex. I have added a
libvirt flag called 'libvirt_console_buffer' which allows the
user to use the console ringbuffer, which allows this option to be
configurable. It is turned off by default.

Change-Id: Ida23f885ad51e6635b6704294bf7ea3c5322ef0b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
Signed-off-by: Robie Basak <robie.basak@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2012-03-04 22:14:12.000000000', 'message': "Only raw string literals should be used with _()

Fix a number of places where formatted strings were used with _() (causing
gettext to not match the string) or variables with _() (causing xgettext
to not extract a string)

Also, there's no value in internationalizing an empty string

Change-Id: Iac7dbe46eeaa8ddf03c2a357ecd52f69aa8678aa
"}]
commit_message:
Only raw string literals should be used with _()

Fix a number of places where formatted strings were used with _() (causing
gettext to not match the string) or variables with _() (causing xgettext
to not extract a string)

Also, there's no value in internationalizing an empty string

Change-Id: Iac7dbe46eeaa8ddf03c2a357ecd52f69aa8678aa

subject: remove pep8 and strict lxml version from setup.py
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 233, 'name': 'Brad Hall', 'email': 'brad@nicira.com', 'username': 'bgh'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 447, 'name': 'dan wendlandt', 'email': 'dan@nicira.com', 'username': 'danwent'}, {'_account_id': 452, 'name': 'Somik Behera', 'email': 'somik@nicira.com', 'username': 'somikbehera'}, {'_account_id': 1452, 'name': 'mandeep-dhami', 'username': 'mandeep-dhami'}, {'_account_id': 2340, 'name': 'Ionut Artarisi', 'email': 'iartarisi@suse.cz', 'username': 'mapleoin'}, {'_account_id': 2350, 'name': 'Willian Molinari', 'email': 'pothix@pothix.com', 'username': 'pothix'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/144/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/75/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Ionut, 

to be honest with you, I do not know why we explicitly need lxml version 2.3. It might even be that, as far as Quantum is concerned, each version of lxml will be fine.

We imported this kind of requirements, as well as most of the wsgi code, from nova. We did it in a kind of 'blind' way for two reasons:
i) Do less work :)
ii) Be ready for switching to openstack-common, which is being extrapolated mainly from nova, as soon as it is ready."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Somik point out the correct reason for which lxml was chosen. 
The same library is used throughout in other openstack projects.
As we barely use it, I will not oppose a decision to remove this dependency and replace it with minidom. Apart from having one less dependency is there another reason for removing it?

Also, keep in mind that we expect all this code to be replaced by openstack-common in the Folsom lifecycle.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While eliminating dependencies in general is a good thing, given that nova requires lxml=2.3 already, I don't see a big win from removing it from the Quantum code base.  

I also agree with Salv's comment that sticking with the openstack "standard" approach makes sense given that we hope this generic code is moved to an openstack-common project in Folsom.'}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I added Salvatore Orlando to the review, he is actively working on the API serialization and deserialization layer and can comment on the necessity.

On a peripheral look, it seems to me that lxml is not strongly required, we just need to use xml marshalling/unmarshalling mechanism that can be fulfilled by any xml parser library. 

With that said, DOM parsers are traditionally memory intensive and not preferred for an API marshalling/unmarshalling layer. A library that uses SAXParser is usually preferred. StaXParser, which is a streaming parser optimized for memory and speed is the best but its much newer than the other two.

A quick look reveals that lxml excel in terms of speed/performance and that might be why it was chosen but Salvatore can comment best.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I found this while trying to package quantum for SUSE. I was irked by the strong lxml = 2.3 dependency and wanted to see why it's needed. 

It's not clear to me why the the _to_xml is needed at all (I can't figure out where it's used), but at least this would remove the need for lxml. Unless there is some magic which lxml does in there and minidom can't that I don't know about..."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your explanations.

I didn't know about this reason for using lxml. I don't really care if it's replaced with minidom or not. If it's not replaced, there should definitely be a comment above that call saying why it's being used instead of minidom.

Also, what is the reason for requiring lxml==2.3 specifically?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/164/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/95/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/181/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/165/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/111/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Looks like it needs a rebase :)'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think its fine to remove the strict versioning as I still don't know why we have it :)  I'll forward this thread to monty to make sure."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

It seems that as far as Quantum is concerned, strict versioning can be removed.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, my main concern was the version in pip-requires.  Brad, is removing the strict versioning from the setup.py OK?  I don't think nova even has requirements in their setup.py (from taking a quick glance).

Ionut, are you ok with leaving it in pip-requires, but removing it from setup.py?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

ok, let's ship this puppy :)"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, so the specific lxml version doesn't work for SUSE?  is that the root of the problem?  How is this being handled for nova, which has the same lxml==2.3 requirement?"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, so if there's no reason for it, can we just removing the strict version checking? lxml==2.3

I updated my patch and also added a comment explaining that lxml is used for performance reasons."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The root problem is that there is a versioned dependency in the setup.py file (and we don't know where it came from). The fact that it doesn't work on SUSE is only its manifestation.

Here's the traceback I get:

# quantum-server
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/quantum-server", line 5, in <module>
    from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2711, in <module>
    parse_requirements(__requires__), Environment()
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 584, in resolve
    raise DistributionNotFound(req)
pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: lxml==2.3

Removing the strict version check from setup.py fixes this issue.

Nova gets around this by not setting requirements in the setup.py file at all. The strict lxml==3.2 version requirement is only in the pip-requires file.

While we're at it, there's also an unneeded requires on pep8 in the setup.py file. I think that shouldn't be in there as pep8 is only required for running the tests.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Fails

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/125/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/126/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/201/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/192/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/122/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build Failed

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/126/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/177/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ship it.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1452, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good. Any reason to prefer lxml vs lxml>=2.3?'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I've rebased and have also removed the pep8 requirement from setup.py. 

Please accept this change as well, otherwise we get silly things like the quantum server failing to start because it wants (but doesn't need) pep8:

# quantum-server 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/quantum-server", line 5, in <module>
    from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2707, in <module>
    working_set.require(__requires__)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 686, in require
    needed = self.resolve(parse_requirements(requirements))
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 584, in resolve
    raise DistributionNotFound(req)
pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: pep8>=0.6.1'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Yes. From the discussion above it showed that there is no reason to prefer any specific version of lxml. Quantum works fine with older versions than 2.3 so there is no reason to enforce an artificial requirement especially since some distributions don't provide support for it."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

bump! Can anyone retrigger the Jenkins build please?'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

If we don't need anything specially related to this version I see no problem on remove the version from this library at all to solve SUSE problem."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Totally agree. Keeping it on pip-requires and removing from setup.py.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-05 16:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

commit_message:
populate glance 'name' field through ec2-register

For images registered via RegisterImage in the ec2 api, populate
glance's 'name' field.  If the name is not supplied in the ec2
request, then set it to be the location.

This has the added value of 'glance index' now showing ec2 registered
images.  Previously, they were not listed because of the empty Name
field.

Additionally, when responding to DescribeImages in the ec2 api,
populate the name field.  Previously we were not populating this at
all.  In the case where there is no name, use image_location.

Fixes bug 930314

Change-Id: I10bcac9ab298a2bf127b5228c62c3cf4f009abd6

During unittest runs it's possible for time.time() - self.start

Change-Id: I20d4b9bf7ff3cdce4e9fe3215622c01cfec7f8bb

commit_message:
Fix a ZeroDivisionError for short replicator runs.

During unittest runs it's possible for time.time() - self.start
to be zero. This patch sets the elapsed value to an arbitrarily
small number to prevent divide by zero errors.

Change-Id: I20d4b9bf7ff3cdce4e9fe3215622c01cfec7f8bb

subject: Fix quantum manager deallocate_for_instance
messages:
[{'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-20 20:48:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'd like to make sure there's a unit test that covers this case, as I'm concerned that unless these semantics are encoded in unit tests, they will break again in the future.  

I'm actually confused as to why the "test_allocate_and_deallocate_instance_dynamic" doesn't trigger this case already, as it should create ports both on a global network (default tenant id) and on networks belonging to 'fake_project2'.  Perhaps there's a logic bug in the test suite?'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-02-20 23:48:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for taking a look, Dan!

I agree--this needs a test. But based on what you see so far, do you agree my change seems like it is striving for more correct behavior?

I think the reason why this problem isn't caught in the testing right now is that our main use cases are instances with ports open on only the default network, or on a network whose tenant id is the same as the project id of the instance. But from my reading of the code, it seems that it should be valid for an instance to be attached to networks that are associated with different projects. Maybe it is invalid globally due to policy, but it seems it should be valid in the quantum manager.

I'll think more about how to put together a good test for this patch. And I'm happy with any suggestions any other reviewers can come up with :-)"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-21 00:17:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Mark,

Thanks for the explanation.  Currently, with QuantumManager, it is only possible to attach a VM to a port on a network that is either owned by the default tenant, or the tenant owner of the VM (this is what the unit test checks for).   I know understand that you're talking about a third case, were a VM is connected to a network that is neither the default tenant nor the tenant owning the VM.  

We do plan on supporting that use case, but before then, all of the code we're currently talking about changing will ripped out (this work is disruptive, and so won't go in until Folsom).  The plan is that networks will no longer even be represented in the Nova DB, and that the virtual_interfaces table in the Nova DB will map directly from virtual interfaces to the corresponding Quantum network + port UUIDs.   This will get rid of a lot of the yucky logic in Quantum Manager, even to the point of being able to eliminate Quantum Manager all together and instead just have calls to directly from nova-compute to Quantum (we'll be discussing this at the Folsom summit).  

So for this patch in particular, if it is needed to achieve a particular use case right now, I think its fine way to achieve it, but it is geared primarily at supporting a future use case, it may not be worth the trouble.  If you do end up adding it, I would add a unit test, as this is not something that was not previously supported."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-03-05 15:28:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

I don't think I'm going to figure out a test for this, but I'm still convinced that the quantum manager is using the wrong logic for determining the tenant-id of the networks its deleting ports from. In particular it is using different logic than that used during port creation."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-20 20:07:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix quantum manager deallocate_for_instance

When deallocating ports for an instance, we should use the tenant id
associated with network the vif is on, rather than the instance's
project id. Otherwise, there will be problems if an instance is attached
to a network associated with a different project.

Change-Id: Iac55258ab34904ff004017048301116d44e139a0
"}]
commit_message:
Fix quantum manager deallocate_for_instance

When deallocating ports for an instance, we should use the tenant id
associated with network the vif is on, rather than the instance's
project id. Otherwise, there will be problems if an instance is attached
to a network associated with a different project.

Change-Id: Iac55258ab34904ff004017048301116d44e139a0

subject: make container_format a mandatory option for "glance add"
messages:
[{'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2012-02-23 07:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1427, 'date': '2012-02-23 07:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-23 09:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Reynolds,

Thanks for the patch.

We had some debate around whether disk and container formats should be mandatory or defaulted.

The outcome from:

  https://review.openstack.org/#change,4272

was to make both formats mandatory, and to ensure consistency by enforcing this requirement within the API layer, so that we'd get the same result regardless of whether the image was added via the CLI or the python/REST APIs.

This approach turned out to be over-restrictive, as in some cases the image is simply being "reserved" by the initial POST and the disk/container formats aren't known until the image content is provided via a subsequent PUT. This led to a loosening of the restriction, such that the disk/container formats need not be supplied when an image is added without any image content initially:

  https://review.openstack.org/#change,4330

Now I'm not sure there's a great deal of value in duplicating this policy in the CLI, but at the very least you'd need to be consistent by checking for both disk & conatiner formats, only enforcing in the cases where the image data is provided on the initial add (i.e. 'glance add < /path/to/image' or 'glance add location=URI' or 'glance add copy_from=URI').

There would be further complication where the image was initially created with neither image content nor disk/container formats specified. The CLI would have to detect this and enforce the requirement for the formats to be present in a subsequent 'glance update location=URI'.

The other option would be for the CLI to simply pass through wharever formats the user provided (as it does now) and allow the cases where a required format is missing to be detected and rejected within the API layer.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-26 21:19:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not submit

I think it makes more sense to allow the API to handle the policy of disk/container_formats being required on activate. We just need to make sure it's handled properly at this level."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-05 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-05 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

commit_message:
make container_format a mandatory option for "glance add"

bug 939257

Check whether the option container_format is specified when user issue "glance add".
If the container_format is not specified, the action will be stopped.
Addtionally, warning messages and helps will be printed as well.

Change-Id: Ieb8a96731a441b065784e99b3b7e810ff3177c87

[{'created': '2012-03-03 18:08:52.000000000', 'message': "assertRaises(Exception, ...) considered harmful

Expecting that Exception is raised can end up passing an a test when an
unexpected error occurs. For instance, errors in the unit test itself
can be masked:

https://review.openstack.org/4848
https://review.openstack.org/4873
https://review.openstack.org/4874

Change a variety of unit tests to expect a more specific exception so
we don't run into false positive tests in the future.

Change-Id: Ibc0c63b1f6b5574a3ce93d9f02c9d1ff5ac4a8b0
"}, {'created': '2012-03-04 19:02:08.000000000', 'message': "assertRaises(Exception, ...) considered harmful

unexpected error occurs. For instance, errors in the unit test itself
can be masked:

https://review.openstack.org/4848
https://review.openstack.org/4873
https://review.openstack.org/4874

Change a variety of unit tests to expect a more specific exception so
we don't run into false positive tests in the future.

Change-Id: Ibc0c63b1f6b5574a3ce93d9f02c9d1ff5ac4a8b0
"}]
commit_message:
assertRaises(Exception, ...) considered harmful

Expecting that Exception is raised can end up passing an a test when an
unexpected error occurs. For instance, errors in the unit test itself
can be masked:

https://review.openstack.org/4848
https://review.openstack.org/4873
https://review.openstack.org/4874

Change a variety of unit tests to expect a more specific exception so
we don't run into false positive tests in the future.

Change-Id: Ibc0c63b1f6b5574a3ce93d9f02c9d1ff5ac4a8b0

Fix test_unrescue to actually test unrescue

Another case where assertRaises(Exception, ...) masked a bug in the
unit test. The unrescue method takes another argument now. When
TypeError was raised, it was caught by the broad match to Exception
as well.

Change-Id: I6b948baa41f2061ea413e14ae6aba054e6f22ecf

subject: Disable submit action button until any of list item is selected
messages:
[{'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-02 06:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is great!'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 07:28:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 07:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

the last patch set only worked on dangerous red button
new patch work on non dangerous form submit button as well'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-02 09:09:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This patch is wrong. For example - look at /syspanel/services/. There are no checkboxes on the page, and the filter form is disabled! This should first check if there are *any* checkboxes in the form, and then to disable anything.


Also, for the *row* actions, I would use something like:

$("form").find(":checkbox").on('click', function(){
  $(this).closest('button.btn-danger').toggleClass('disabled');
});
This code is not supposed to be valid, just as an idea. To toggle button class only if the row checkbox is clicked and not any of the checkboxes.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 09:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 09:58:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

nice catch Tihomir Trifonov
I fix the bug you found, and it should work properly now.

I didn't write the toggleClass that way because the button should only be enable if any of the checkbox is checked, and disabled only when all checkbox is cleared"}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-02 15:45:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

The patch now (almost) works, just needs a small selector fix, as it currently affects the 'Filter' buttons."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-02 15:47:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Ah, also for the snippet in my first comment - disregard. The row buttons do not need to be disabled.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:34:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

this final change should work as expected, sorry for missing that previous check on filter button, I only checked /syspanel/service and thought it was fixed, will be more careful nexttime'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-03-02 17:13:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Okay, works now.. but.. sorry for pushing on this.. just noticed something else, a minor but annoying issue ;)

  $("form :checkbox").click(function (evt) {

It is better to implement this using live() or on('click', function())

The reason for that are the modal windows in /nova/access_and_security, "Edit Rules". And all other modal forms having checkboxes. They need dynamically binding of the events.
But this leads to another problem, which I am not sure how could be solved. For modal forms - the initial check for 

  $("form").each(function (i) {
    var checkboxes = $(this).find(":checkbox")

cannot be performed. It is done once on document.ready()... One solution is to move the form validation functions(initial validation) into a separate function to be called once on document.ready(), and once again after a modal form is rendered, if the modal form needs some additional processing... Or if there is some other way to dynamically enforce the checkbox checks...'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 17:59:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 18:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

how this looks, I added the same check on the modal generation on ajax-modal, not sure if this is the best way to do this'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-03-03 01:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-03 03:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-03 03:30:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

subject: set image attributes not modifiable as read-only
messages:
[{'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-02 06:33:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Actually, I think instead of allowing the length to be longer, we should make the field readonly.

Given the insights from glance people in this bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/944509 - I don't think many of the fields we have should be editable at all (especially ID)"}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 06:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

if this field is not editable, why it is handled in the form.py for this model?'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-02 06:50:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think that the fields need to be present to give the user context for the fields which are editable, therefore belong in the ModalForm view as non-editable items.

For example if I open a modal form and I want to edit the ramdisk id, I should be able to quickly see in the form what actual image id is without being able to edit it.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 07:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

so what you mean is it is editable, but not in its current form?'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 11:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It would make sense to provide a list of available kernels and ramdisks instead of using a text field for kernel_id and ramdisk_id.'}, {'account_id': 2654, 'date': '2012-03-02 17:13:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

the kernel_id and ramdisk_id textfield is set as read-only for this patch set, so it's not editable

and a list of available choices for both of them isn't that feasible in my opinion, there could be a lot of them in production deployment, and it's not that usable from UI point of view to choose a long gibberish uuid from a dropdown list

maybe there is a need for extra view/page to handle this?"}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-03-03 01:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2012-03-03 03:13:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Prevents fade-in of modal forms in case of
existing previous modal form.
Note: This is just a quick fix for the problem specified in the bug.
In general there are problems with using overlaying modals.
Each subsequent modal form doesn't 'backdrop' the previous one,
and the first modal could be closed without closing the last one.

Fixes bug 944502

Change-Id: I8086dcd14f5fbfb3c9d69a7f2f20e62e012b294e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-02 23:53:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix test_migrate_disk_and_power_off_exception

The test asserts that Exception is raised, which means any number of
failures within the test itself will cause it to pass. In this case
there were two bugs in the test case:

1) Too many arguments to migrate_disk_and_power_off
2) fake_get_instance_disk_info should return a JSON string

I changed the assert to catch an AssertionError exception instead to
avoid this kind of bug in the future

Change-Id: I5e0f57b093ee1b2830696542d343c2dd89c383d6
'}]
commit_message:
Fix test_migrate_disk_and_power_off_exception

The test asserts that Exception is raised, which means any number of
failures within the test itself will cause it to pass. In this case
there were two bugs in the test case:

1) Too many arguments to migrate_disk_and_power_off
2) fake_get_instance_disk_info should return a JSON string

I changed the assert to catch an AssertionError exception instead to
avoid this kind of bug in the future

Change-Id: I5e0f57b093ee1b2830696542d343c2dd89c383d6

subject: Set PolicyNotAuthorized HTTP Return Code
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-24 06:23:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Something is funky here.

The exception should be getting wrapped by ResourceExceptionHandler in
nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py:

 573         if isinstance(ex_value, exception.NotAuthorized):
 574             msg = unicode(ex_value)
 575             raise Fault(webob.exc.HTTPForbidden(explanation=msg))

I don't think we want to wrap at compute and volume api layers, we want it wrapped in the wsgi stack where it is.

The problem is that RemoteErrors aren't getting wrapped properly, so what we really need here is another check for Remote error
elif isinstance(ex_value, exception.RemoteError) and then a check on the RemoteError to see if it is a NotAuthorized exception of some sort.

This may require RemoteError storing the original type of the exception in an identifiable way.  Right now I think it just stores the text from the exception.

At one point I tried to make RemoteErrors reraise the same exception on the calling side, we may be able to do something like that."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-03 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-03 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

[{'created': '2012-02-24 05:36:23.000000000', 'message': 'Set PolicyNotAuthorized HTTP Return Code

Change PolicyNotAuthorized code to 403 in exceptions
Catch exceptions for PolicyNotAuthorized in compute, volume, network api and return webob.exc.HTTPForbidden()

Fixes bug 917897

Change-Id: I6ba27e3f42bc45fe470500c828c63afac2a1fea0
'}]
commit_message:
Set PolicyNotAuthorized HTTP Return Code

Change PolicyNotAuthorized code to 403 in exceptions
Catch exceptions for PolicyNotAuthorized in compute, volume, network api and return webob.exc.HTTPForbidden()

Fixes bug 917897

Change-Id: I6ba27e3f42bc45fe470500c828c63afac2a1fea0

commit_message:
Tell user instance not found.

Displays an error when an instance is not found
when looking for an individual instance. This
is the same behavior when using eucatools from EC2.
Fixes bug 836978.

Change-Id: I956fa16aa989b31ea8b6d6daeb6d78ccdc32ba66
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

Should we be switching the default for Essex?  If so, it might be an appropriate time to rename it to something that makes sense.  I think 'Distributed' really meant that it was zone-aware.. which is not the case anymore."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:25:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris: How about FilterScheduler? I guess the concern would be if anyone has a flagfile that is using it from diablo, as changing the name will break it. commit_message:
Improve exercise robustness

* Test returns and exit codes on most command invocations
* Add start and end banners to make output easier to find in
  long log files
* Adds die_if_error(), die_if_not_set() and is_set() to functions
* Add some function tests

Fixes bug 944593

Change-Id: I55e2962c5fec9aad237b674732b1e922ad37a62e

subject: Fix bug 872558 - potential race condition in locking
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-02 21:53:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

This patch can't possibly fix the bug reported. Execution can't be interrupted between checking if the key is in the dict and setting the dict. Green Threads must explicitly switch context for that to happen."}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-03-02 23:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You're right - this doesn't fix the problem reported.

Will add a unit test, and a correct fix if really necessary after testing."}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-03-03 01:41:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Unit tests are fine, and I can't reproduce the original bug. Abandoning."}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-03-03 01:41:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Not a valid fix.'}]

commit_message:
Fix bug 872558 - potential race condition in locking

Adds a semaphore to protect dynamic allocation and deletion of
semaphores in the utils.synchronized decorator.

Change-Id: I20108522c3ee50aae535a878ff7ab2fa4813b9ae

subject: Adds soft-reboot support to libvirt
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-01 16:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

This is an important one.

Is 20s enough? I'd have thought at least 30.
A couple of suggested comment tweaks are inline"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-01 16:49:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Small typo inline... but code looks good overall."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:12:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the input guys. I fixed the comments.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:19:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

added a test to force the soft reboot to fallback to a hard reboot.  I'm not totally in love with the libvirt_wait_reboot_seconds name for the flag since it is actually implemented as a series of attempts with a 1 second delay. Should it be libvirt_shutdown_check_attempts or something?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:26:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:41:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:44:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

updated flag.

Brian: Defaulting to 'HARD' seems wrong since the corresponding method in the manager defaults to 'SOFT'.  I also think it is nasty for rescue/unrescue to use be using the public method and passing in an extra xml parameter.  I cleaned it up by pulling out into an internal _hard_reboot method and letting rescue and unrescue use that. I think this makes the interaction much clearer."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:45:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I like this a lot, Vish. The refactoring had occurred to me but I didn't want to ask you to do it for the scope of this bug. Thanks for doing it!"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

nice one. cheers'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:28:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Looks great.  Some apps e.g. databases can take a very long time to shutdown, because they have to flush dirty buffers to disk (i.e. write close to 16GB of data on a 16GB instance), and so you'd have to pick a very big allowed shutdown time window.  As an API caller, I'm going to have my own timing logic anyway, and so for that use case ideally a soft reboot would never become hard.  However, I can see why you want the timing logic, because otherwise machines could get stuck in the shutdown state (though I thought we had code that would restart them?).

I don't think there's a clean answer here, so instead this behavior should be very clearly documented, so that users know e.g. to tell their database to flush to disk, before sending the soft reboot command, so that the soft shutdown will succeed inside the allowed window."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Honestly, I think our api decisions might be a little off here.  I would think that there should be two separate commands instead of needing to fallback.  That is a more extensive change though, so in the meantime, should we increase the timeout to 60 seconds+

I would think that if a user is going in to flush buffers etc. anyway, it probably would be easier to just issue a reboot command from the guest.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:37:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

that was a question: should we increase the timeout to 60 seconds?'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:43:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

At least. I'm not-so-firmly in the camp of "No Fallback". From a customer's perspective (using the OSAPI) they'll issue a soft reboot and the state will be REBOOT while the reboot signal is sent until the server is powered off.

It would make sense for the server to be stuck in REBOOT IMO and after a while if still unsuccessful the user could send a hard_reboot action to put the server in HARD_REBOOT state.

It's a nice feature to have, but I'd be much more comfortable with it at least being optional.

Code looks fine for current feature-set.

+1 on 60 seconds or more for default'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:58:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Lamar: I was attempting to mirror what happens in xenapi.  My reading of the cleanup code in vm_ops was that there is a periodic check for stuck rebooting instances and a hard_reboot is automatically issued.  I want feature parity, so if this is incorrect, I will remove the fallback and just let it stay in rebooting'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:16:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Gotcha. I wasn't even thinking about parity and while I think we'll end up re-visiting this from a customer perspective, feature parity is the right move."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:37:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1996/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1645/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1276/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3026/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-01 22:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

appears to be a temporary failure in jenkins, but I used the window to update the default timeout to 120 seconds.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-01 22:17:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1996/ : SUCCESS

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3026/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1279/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-01 22:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3026/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1283/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-03-02 14:57:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm happier the extra 100 seconds. cheers."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:37:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Somebody else can push this back in.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-02 23:28:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Adds soft-reboot support to libvirt

 * Falls back to hard reboot if guest doesn't respond
 * Cleans up reboot/rescue/unrescue interaction
 * Fixed fake for tests
 * Added a force hard reboot test to verify fallback works
 * Fixes bug 939557

Change-Id: I8d0c9a35725de5e5bfb8f13a2d869c6122ba44ef

commit_message:
One last redux for setup.py requirement parsing.

Working around some limitations of setuptools/distribute/distutils
in order to get the right versions of everything installed.

Splits requirements out between core requirements and testing
requirements.

Change-Id: I2157527a91041a6297efe689b2a709f47fc605d8

  CreateRegisterImagesTest.test_register_then_upload
  CreateRegisterImagesTest.test_register_with_invalid_data

commit_message:
Pass credentials to glance client.

The auth creds dict was created but not passed to the glance client,
causing the following tests to fail with 401 Unauthorized:

  CreateRegisterImagesTest.test_register_then_upload
  CreateRegisterImagesTest.test_register_with_invalid_data

Change-Id: Icca9632f5de66ee7e957116e8dc60b53de9c1c87

commit_message:
standardize ldap and related tests

ldap was accidentally supplying some of its own values rather than using
the built-in fixtures, so it was providing the incorrect interface for a
couple calls.

also adds a test for get_user_by_name (skipped for ldap) and
standardizes the kvs and ldap authenticate calls

fix user authentication live ldap tests
Change-Id: If1ccce1fd9c84622bb89344bc5d5c59b059d03ae

subject: task moves stuck building instances to error
messages:
[{'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-28 22:54:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Relatively minor nits, and a possible keystone problem."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-02-28 23:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Thanks for the review, comments inline and another patch is on the way.'}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-02-29 00:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-29 00:05:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-29 00:06:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-02-29 10:01:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Aaron,

We've been workign with something similar for a while now in our owncode base, the reason we didn't submit it so far is that when I proposed this as part of the state management blueprint in Boston folks were very unhappy with this particular aspect - general feeling was that they didn't think Nova could anticipate how long an image might take to load (still seems a good idea to us ;-)

However one thing you do need to add into your code is that even if you set the state to Error there is a chance that the eventlet handling the build is still running (we've seen builds complete after several hours under some error conditions) - and in teh current code that will then put the state back to "Active", which is pretty confusing to the user.    So if you're adding this timeout capaibilty you also need to add code in the create patch (for example after image downlaod and anywhere else where it would update the state) to check if the state is still building - and if it isn't to exit gracefully.'}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-03-01 22:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-03-02 09:25:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Aaron,

Patch set 3 doesn;t seem to have addreses the concerns that I raised - so maybe I didn't explain them clearly enough.  

Its not enough to just set vm_state to Error in one eventlet if you want to have consistent behaviour, you also need to modify the code in _run_instance execution path (which may well still be running in another eventlet) to detect that the state has changed and abandon its work on creating the VM).  One way to do this it to check everytime the code goes to update vm_state that its still has the expected value.  If the state has changed (could be because your code has put it to error, or because its been deleted), then the eventlet needs to clean up and exit.  Same check is needed in virt - as your timer could also pop during the libvirt connection.

Happy to discuss this more here or by e-mail (phil.day@hp.com) if that would help."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:44:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I didn't realize we set the instance state to BUILDING _everywhere_ during this process(even before its scheduled). My thoughts here were that if driver.spawn took to long we could check the instance state once it returned(if it did return without raising), and the raise to let _run_instance run it's cleanup methods. _run_instance calls _spawn directly, so I thought the raise would trigger the cleanup. The problem is that the periodic task could catch an instance thats not just in _spawn because the vm_state is set to BUILDING in the api.

Sorry for not searching out where BUILDING was set before submitting this. I'll dig around and see what the plans are for cleaning up the state management and see what better solutions could be worked on."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Looking for a better solution.'}]

commit_message:
task moves stuck building instances to error

This periodic task will find instances on the host
that have been in building for more than
building_timeout seconds and move them to error.

This adds two new flags:
building_timeout - number of seconds to let an
				   instance build before moving
				   it to error
stuck_building_poll_interval - frequency to run
                               the cleanup job, in
                               scheduler ticks

update: address some of Michael's comments
update: added a check to ComputeManager's _spawn
        to make sure the instance should be active
        after the manager finishes spawning it.

Change-Id: I364358d64e9dbabaaf6872cc3982ee96371a5afe

Python will call into the parent classes implementation of setUp/tearDown
if there is no implementation in the child

Also, make sure all setUp implementations subclassed off test.TestClass
call the parent setUp so everything gets setup correctly

Change-Id: If410cd412d9557a0d3172ec96b592fbd3fd67ffd
'}]
commit_message:
Remove empty setUp/tearDown methods

Python will call into the parent classes implementation of setUp/tearDown
if there is no implementation in the child

Also, make sure all setUp implementations subclassed off test.TestClass
call the parent setUp so everything gets setup correctly

Change-Id: If410cd412d9557a0d3172ec96b592fbd3fd67ffd

subject: Refactor spawn to use UndoManager.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-29 23:51:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is a refactoring that aims to make it easier to work with the `spawn` method in vmops.

The main goal is to provide a consistent way of undo'ing tasks. This is accomplished via a contextmanager which maintains a stack of undo_func closures.

Each step is considered atomic, so we only undo if the step finished successfully (and the next step failed). This means we should, time permitting, be breaking these steps into finer and finer granularity to improve undo-ability.

This refactoring should aid in a future patch to address the issue of swap disk being left behind when a spawn errors outs. (To address this, swap creation will be moved into the create_disks step and the deleting swap will be moved into undo_create_disks, similar to how kernel and ramdisk were refactored)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 00:05:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

In general I love this.  1 comment inline.  And I'm trying to think if there's a slightly better interface...  (which we're discussing offline right now)"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 00:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 00:12:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 01:57:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 01:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The patch has been updated to:

1. Use comstud's suggestion of defaulting `exceptions = Exception`
2. Use johannes' suggestion of having the step-decorator keep track of total and current steps itself.

Future work would include:

1. Fixing resize to use the new-fangled step decorator
2. Fixing swap being left behind issue by adding undo task for it."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

Great comments Johannes. Stay tuned.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:51:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This version:

  * Gets rid of unecessary decorator layer
  * Goes with explicit try/except/rollback rather than context-manager.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:54:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 02:55:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

* Docstring typo-fix.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-03-01 12:17:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Minor comments/suggestions. 

I rate this -1, neverthless this does not mean that I strongly object to this refactoring being merged as is. 

That said, as there is no loss of functionality without this, I wouldn't rush in getting it in, and I'd suggest an extra couple of iterations to get it spot-on, and a great example/pattern for other pieces of Nova to be refactored in the same way.

Just a thought."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-03-01 15:22:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

This looks cool to me, but I'm still quite new to our style of programing and I have trouble following the huge list of inner functions that separate the actual body of spawn from its implementation. Since there is so much functionality here it might be worth breaking out into some kind of spawn controller. This would reduce spawn to something that delegates out to the spawner, And everything else could be contained there(or even all of that orchestration could be within the spawner).

This would help with Armondo's suggestion and make testing these inner methods, and the rollbacks, easier. It seems to me like you are continuing the trend of having the mechanics of talking to the instance mixed with the orchestration of that. If you split it apart the Spawner (or maybe SpawnManager?) could be an UndoManager, and you could keep the decorator and the instance state within that.

My other worry is that we don't have anything that manages the state transitions. I'm running into this problem with the moving instances to ERROR after being in BUILD for to long. So that may be coloring my view of this patch."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 15:28:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Reading the subsequent comments got me thinking that there will likely be overlap with the orchestration work that still needs to be done.

It's likely large workflows like this will need to be broken up into steps that are handled by the orchestration system. This patch will likely have to change again if that happens."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 16:16:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (3 inline comments)

Responding to Armando inline.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 16:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Aaron & Johannes: Agree (for the most part) with your points.

The more I think about this, the more I lean towards using a full-on Command pattern here. At the risk of Java-fying the code, that would give us step counting, undoability, better testability, and arguably make it easier to read.

The downside is the code will grow much larger and become (in some ways) more complex as well as being a major pain to refactor to.

For these reasons, I'd propose that we treat this patch as an intermediate step.

This gets us started by breaking processes down into step functions with undo handlers attached, that should be a easier, down the road, to port over to Command (Step, Action) objects.

The other benefit we get immediately, is it helps us avoid many of those "forgot-to-cleanup" bugs we've been seeing (just had two in a so many days, not shutting down the VM, not cleaning up swap), by keeping the do and undo handlers spatially near other.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 17:10:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I agree that the current state is really poor and we should do something right now.

I'm ok with an intermediate solution, but I'd encourage as simple of a solution as possible since it will almost certainly change at some point.

Putting the undo logic with the do logic is a good idea. I wish Python had something like the D scope(failure) statement since that is pretty much what we are trying to do here."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:06:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

This version:

  * Moves step decorator into vmops (the only place it will be used) and avoids the possibility of circular import

My vote (style-nits aside) is that we merge this in as an intermediate step towards a more general (complex) cleanup down the road.

Once this merges, I can start work on fixing the issue of generated swap failing to be cleaned up.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 18:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Updated commit msg to be more accurate and put the patch in context of a larger refactor.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:13:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

inline"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:21:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:28:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

if this is going to be cleaned up/refactored later, I am not going to hold this back. Good work, btw.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:30:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Typofix, unit-test fixes forthcoming!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:44:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 19:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 20:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-03-01 20:29:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is some awesome stuff. We will probably mirror some of this functionality in network land. Also, I agree with rick that this is a good intermediate step. uh +1 for now while you're refactoring the exceptions."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 20:30:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not sure if it's worth the effort to fix right now (but maybe add a comment), but you can still leak resources after your patch. For instance, the kernel image gets leaked if the ramdisk image fails to build. This may be what you were talking about in switching to micro steps.

Also, I'm not so sure that closures are required for the cleanup functions. The cleanup functions could search for the VDIs and VM instead of being passed the references. The VM can be looked up by the name (indeed _create_vm does this to prevent duplicates). The VDIs could be created with the appropriate names in the glance plugin and looked up that way.

Maybe change _destroy_vm to do this so the same code path could destroy partially built VMs and fully built VMs. It would require some reorganization since _destroy_vm uses VBDs to destroy VDIs which may not be setup yet in a partially built VM.

Anyway, mostly thoughts for the future."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 20:42:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Johannes: Yeah that's what I meant by micro-steps.

In these cases, I think you're right, we could find the orphaned objects later using some kind of search on name-label, and that would avoid the need for a closure.

I'm not certain that will work in all cases, so I wanted the undo-state to be explicit (as in passed in), or implicit (inherited from the outer scope).

Just as an example, imagine a VDI is created, no label attached yet, and no VBD record is created to associate it with the VM. In this hypothetical example, it would be very difficult to track and cleanup this specific VDI later on. But if we memorize the VDI in a list which the undo_func gets access to, it's trivial. That was the thinking at least."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 20:56:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

That's the current case, where the glance plugin doesn't touch the VDI metadata, but there's no reason why the glance plugin can't setup the metadata to make it easy to find.

The reason why I bring this up is that there are lots of failure scenarios. For instance, the glance plugin can do all of the work it normally does, but for some reason the connection between dom0 and nova-compute drops and the response never gets received by nova-compute. You've just leaked some VDIs right there. It's probably pretty rare, but it would be nice if we didn't have to use a script to garbage collect orphaned VDIs.

The safest way to clean up is to search for partially setup resources, especially when you're dealing with communication between systems and sporadic failure isn't unheard of.

All that said, I'm still fine with your intermediate solution."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Recently something went in to tag the VM rec with "nova_uuid" by throwing it under "other-config".  We should do that for VDIs, etc, as well, if it's not being done.

I don't think there's an efficient way to search on that key without scanning everything... but it would make it easy to clean up things on error.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-01 21:40:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I spent some time looking at the XenAPI docs and there only appears to be an easy way to search for the name-label. We could set the name-label to the be the same for all VDIs for a VM, and then set an other-config key with the type (os, swap, etc)

This also brings up the issue of how to retroactively set this for all of the VMs created before we did something like this.

Also, we'd probably want to use a statically configured name since changing instance_name_template would probably screw stuff up.

Another option would be to get a full list of the VDIs and iterate that. Right now we can only get a maximum of about 128 VMs per box, so it's too bad to brute force it. Maybe not a good long term solution assuming memory keeps getting cheaper and more plentiful.

Also, another option would be to create the VM first and attach VDIs to it as we go on. We could keep the same logic we have right now in that case.

Just thinking out loud :)"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 23:42:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-01 23:47:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

The most recent revision of the patch:

  * Fixes up a test that only had worked by coincidence (test_spawn_glance). It had been returning a kernel=None which doesn't equal kernel="" so the test passed. In reality, the test should be getting something like kernel="kernel" to really signify that an external kernel was being used with the instance.

  * The other test indicated a real error. The problem was the kernel and vdi steps were conflated causing them not to be cleaned up properly. Breaking them up into two separate steps fixed the test.

Ideally we would breakup kernel from ramdisk, but I don't think it's a big enough issue at this point to worry about, though it certainly should be fixed up down the road as we march towards Operation Baby Steps.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-02 01:00:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-03-02 04:13:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-02 04:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-02 04:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:01:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-03-02 16:18:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified

UndoManager provides a mechanism for automatically rolling back on

commit_message:
Refactor spawn to use UndoManager.

UndoManager provides a mechanism for automatically rolling back on
exceptions.  An additional benefit of this approach is that undo code is
spatially close to the roll-forward code.

This patch should be considered an intermediate step towards a more
complete Command pattern based approach down the road.

Change-Id: Ib429420d67324422a5d13cdea6872fd9c57c857e

commit_message:
Make initial ring balance robust to "holes".

Make initial ring building robust to "holes" (None values in self.devs).
Having these None values in the self.devs array is fine later in the
builder file's life.  Making it okay upon initial balance makes
builder files easier to programatically manipulate.

Change-Id: Icca9c1aa4fd0aae12168998acc39e52f95989b7d

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary setting up and down of mox and stubout

test.TestCase already sets up self.mox and self.stubs as well as calling
self.mox.UnsetStubs(), self.stubs.UnsetAll(), self.stubs.SmartUnsetAll()
and self.mox.VerifyAll() during tearDown.

Change-Id: I74f0824ca1e8daa7b0ee7d7a62b226ba51206e6f

commit_message:
Fix invalid template name in refresh view.  Fixes bug 927412

At some point there was some renaming of templates, the refresh view
wasn't updated and now refers on an invalid template.  The template name
changed from _instance_list.html to _list.html.

Change-Id: I754b8d45bbb0bec7fa80c29001b3f5808d0b7d86
